makers.displaymaker: attributed to Jacques-Louis David, 1748–1825; born Paris, France; died Brussels, Belgium; active Paris, Brussels, and Rome, Italy

texts.textentryhtml: Figure drawing was at the very core of the academic program of the French Académie Royale de Peinture et de Sculpture. Drawings made after the nude, such as this one, were executed by students or by a professor, as an example for the class. Instruction was tightly regimented at the French academy: students first drew countless copies after engravings in line alone, progressing to the study of tonal values drawn in colored chalk from plaster casts of antique sculpture. Only after a proficient level of mastery had been achieved were students finally allowed to draw directly from live models.

Mathias Polakovits;

Gift to the Princeton University Art Museum
